Award.AwardTitle: Operation SWAB: Monitoring of Ship, Van, and Laboratory 14C and 3H Contamination
Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal asks for 5 additional years of support for the SWAB program. The SWAB program has been going on for nearly 30 years as the mechanism for keeping tritium (3H) and radiocarbon (14C) contamination of ships and associated vans and laboratories to a minimum. The SWAB program proposes to continue operations in order to minimize contamination on ships involved in measuring natural abundances of 14C and 3H as part of global ocean programs such as CLIVAR and IOCCP.

Broader Impacts:
The principal impact of the present proposal is under criterion two, providing infrastructure support for scientists to use the vessel and its shared-use instrumentation in support of their NSF-funded oceanographic research projects (which individually undergo separate review by the relevant research program of NSF). The acquisition, maintenance and operation of shared-use instrumentation allows NSF-funded researchers from any US university or lab access to working, calibrated instruments for their research, reducing the cost of that research, and expanding the base of potential researchers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Operation SWAB is a project to help make sure that the UNOLS research fleet does not get contaminated with the radioactive isotopes carbon 14 and tritium. Some researchers bring these isotopes on board the ships at higher than natural concentration to conduct biological experiments. Other researchers want to measure these isotopes at their natural levels. All of the enhanced concentration experimants are conducted in designated lab vans that are isolated from the labs inside the ships. We SWAB test the ships to help make sure that the enhanced level isotopes do not contaminate the lab spaces inside the ship. This project has successfully been testing the UNOLS fleet for more than 30 years and is helping make sure that researchers who want to measure natural levels of carbon 14 and tritium can do so with some assurance that their samples will not be contaminated. Most of the time we do not find any contamination inside the ships.

SInce these isotopes are also radioactive our testing of the surfaces inside the ship provides some assurance to the ship's crew that their living and working spaces are not being contaminated by radioactivity.

Operation SWAB is also set up to help protect the National Ocean Sciences Accelerator Mass Spectrometer facility from carbon 14 contamination. This facility analyzes many of the natural level carbon 14 samples collected at sea and the instruments can be negatively affected by carbon14 contamination.
